{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 176 386}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=823 |title= Clock House (Palaeoentomology) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 October 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1002946}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002946.pdf Citation] |The pit exposes temperate and subtropical [[palaeoenvironment]]s of the [[Lower Cretaceous]] [[Weald Clay Group]]. The site is particularly important for its several thousand fossil insects, including the first described social insect, a termite. There are also aquatic plants, fish and reptiles.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002946.pdf |title=Clock House Brickworks citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 6 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Colony Bog and Bagshot Heath]] | [[File:Cattle on Brentmoor Heath - geograph.org.uk - 1350278.jpg|100px|alt=Colony Bog and Bagshot Heath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 1,130.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001957&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Colony Bog and Bagshot Heath |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=30 September 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Woking]]

Areas of open heath provide a habitat for a variety of heathland bird species to breed.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001957.pdf |title=Colony Bog and Bagshot Heath citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 6 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Colyers Hanger]] | [[File:Waterloo Pond - geograph.org.uk - 547225.jpg|100px|alt=Colyers Hanger]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 26.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000066&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=| title=Designated Sites View: Colyers Hanger |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Guildford]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 036 482}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, p. 50 [[Surrey Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web|url= https://www.surreywildlifetrust.org/nature-reserves/st-marthas-hill-colyers-hanger |title= St Martha's Hill & Colyer's Hanger |publisher= Surrey Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 14 November 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1000066}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000066.pdf Citation] |This is an area of ancient forest on a south facing slope. It has a variety of woodland types due to the geological diversity of the escarpment at different levels. At the bottom is a stream with poorly drained woodland dominated by [[Alnus glutinosa|alder]] and a ground layer with plants such as [[marsh marigold]] and [[pendulous sedge]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000066.pdf|title=Colyers Hanger citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 6 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Combe Bottom]] | [[File:Juniper Hill - geograph.org.uk - 460537.jpg|100px|alt=Combe Bottom]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 42.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000096&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Combe Bottom |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Guildford]]

This is one of the most important sites in the county for invertebrates, including a threatened beetle, ''[[Rhizophagus oblongicollis]]'' and three nationally rare species, the beetle ''[[Bibloporus minutus]]'' and the flies ''[[Ctenophora bimaculata]]'' and ''[[Oedalea apicalis]]''.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000129.pdf |title=Epsom and Ashtead Commons citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 7 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Esher Commons]] | [[File:West End, Esher, 8th February 2011.jpg|100px|alt=Esher Commons]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 360.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000780&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Esher Commons |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=30 September 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Esher]]

However, there is still an outstanding community of invertebrates, and rare species include the water beetle ''[[Graphoderus cinereus]]'', the ladybird ''[[Coccinella distincta]]'' and the bark beetle ''[[Platypus cylindrus]]''.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000780.pdf |title=Esher Commons citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 7 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|G}}[[Glover's Wood]] | [[File:Pond in Glover's Wood - geograph.org.uk - 1756331.jpg|100px|alt=Glover's Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 74.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000805&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Glover's Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Horley]]

The site is also important for invertebrates, especially [[craneflies]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000828.pdf |title=Godstone Ponds citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 8 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Gong Hill]] | [[File:Gong Hill 2.jpg|100px|alt=Gong Hill]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 5.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003016&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Gong Hill |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Farnham]]

The invertebrate population is outstanding, with many nationally rare and uncommon species, such as the beetles ''[[Notolaemus unifasciatus]]'', which is found on dead wood, ''[[Silvanus bidentatus]]'', which feeds on fungus, and the water beetle ''[[Agabus melanarius]]''. There are two nationally rare moths.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000922.pdf |title=Leith Hill citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 9 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Lingfield Cernes]] | | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 10.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000950&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Lingfield Cernes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} | align="center"| | [[Edenbridge, Kent|Edenbridge]]

Mole Gap has a variety of [[Quaternary]] landforms and there are well developed river cliffs where [[alluvial fan]]s have diverted the [[River Mole]] against the valley sides.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000977.pdf |title=Mole Gap to Reigate Escarpment citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 9 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Moor Park SSSI|Moor Park]] | [[File:Alder Carr Wetlands - geograph.org.uk - 671314.jpg|100px|alt=Moor Park]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 6.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001027&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Moor Park |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Farnham]]

{{gbmappingsmall|SU 868 458}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001027}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001027.pdf Citation] |This site in the valley of the [[River Wey]] is mainly [[alder carr]], which is a nationally rare habitat. It is dominated by [[Alnus glutinosa|alder]], with some [[crack willow]]. An area of swamp is mainly covered by [[common reed]], with other plants including [[Alisma plantago-aquatica| water-plantain]], [[marsh violet]], [[Chrysosplenium|opposite leaved golden-saxifrage]] and [[Water dropwort|hemlock water dropwort]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001027.pdf |title=Moor Park citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 14 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|N}}[[Netherside Stream Outcrops]] | [[File:Netherside Stream Outcrops 3.jpg|100px|alt=Netherside Stream Outcrops]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 2.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005890&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Netherside Stream Outcrops |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Haslemere]]

Rare species include the [[white-faced darter]] dragonfly and the ''[[Thyridanthrax fenestratus]]'' bee fly.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001052.pdf |title=Ockham and Wisley Commons citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 14 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|P}}[[Papercourt Marshes|Papercourt]] | [[File:The River Wey Navigation near Papercourt SSSI - geograph.org.uk - 96583.jpg|100px|alt=Papercourt]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 70.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001037&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Papercourt |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Woking]]

Crooksbury Common is important for the protected [[smooth snake]] and [[sand lizard]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001070.pdf |title=Puttenham and Crooksbury Commons citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|Q}}[[Quarry Hangers]] | [[File:Quarry Hangers Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 794691.jpg|100px|alt=Quarry Hangers]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 28.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001091&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Quarry Hangers |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Redhill, Surrey|Redhill]]

There is a taller sward in less grazed areas, with grasses such as [[upright brome]] and [[wood false-brome]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001091.pdf |title=Quarry Hangers citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|R}}[[Ranmore Common SSSI|Ranmore Common]] | [[File:Ranmore Common Bridleway - geograph.org.uk - 560363.jpg|100px|alt=Ranmore Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 224.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001108&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Ranmore Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Dorking]]
{{coord|51.247|-0.364 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Ranmore Common }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 143 510}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001108}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001108.pdf Citation] |This site is mainly woodland, some of it ancient, but there are also areas of heath and rough pasture. There is a diverse community of breeding birds and invertebrates include the [[Idaea subsericeata|satin wave]] moth and the [[Limenitis camilla|white admiral]] butterfly.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001108.pdf |title=Ranmore Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Reigate Heath]] | [[File:Reigate Heath - geograph.org.uk - 632959.jpg|100px|alt=Reigate Heath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 61.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001127&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Reigate Heath |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Reigate]]

{{coord|51.225|-0.714 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Seale Chalk Pit }}
{{gbmappingsmall|SU 899 481}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2573 |title= Seale Chalk Pit (Alpine Structures of Southern England) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 28 October 2018}} [[Surrey Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web|url= https://www.surreywildlifetrust.org/nature-reserves/seale-chalk-pit-meadow |title= Seale Chalk Pit and Meadow |publisher= Surrey Wildlife Trust |accessdate=16 November 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1001140}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001140.pdf Citation] |This former quarry exposes rocks of the [[Hog’s Back]], and exhibits the separation of the folding [[Mesozoic]] rocks of the [[Weald]] from the [[Tertiary]] sediments of the [[London Basin]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001140.pdf |title=Seale Chalk Pit citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sheepleas]] | [[File:Bluebells, Mountain Wood.jpg|100px|alt=heepleas]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 99.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001171&SiteName=&countyCode=41&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Sheepleas |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Leatherhead]]

{{dynamic_list}} This is a list of undomesticated or feral plants, generally considered [[weed]]s, yet having some positive effects or uses, often being ideal as [[companion plant]]s in gardens.
[[Beneficial weed]]s can accomplish a number of roles in the garden or yard, including fertilizing the soil, increasing moisture, acting as shelter or [[living mulch]], repelling pests, attracting [[beneficial insects]], or serving as food or other resources for human beings.

Common name !! Scientific name || Companion plant for || Attracts/hosts || Repels || Traps || Edibility || Medicinal || Avoid || Comments |- | '''[[Bashful mimosa]]''' || ''Mimosa pudica'' || Ground cover for tomatoes, peppers || predatory beetles || || || || || || Used as a natural ground cover in agriculture |- |'''[[Caper spurge]]''' || ''Euphorbia lathyris'' || || ||Moles || || || Used in French folk medicine as an [[emetic]] and [[purgative]]<ref name=purdue>Purdue University: [http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/duke_energy/Euphorbia_lathyris.html Euphorbia lathyris]</ref> || || Many domesticated animals can eat it, although it is poisonous to humans.<ref name=purdue/> |- | '''[[Crow garlic]]''' || ''Allium vineale'' || fruit trees, nightshades (tomatoes, peppers, potatoes, etc.), brassicas (cabbage, broccoli, kohlrabi, etc.) carrots || || slugs, aphids, [[carrot fly]], cabbage worms<ref>[http://www.warren-wilson.edu/~research/Undergrad_Res/nss97-98/fall1997abs.html nss abstracts<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>|| || Can be used like conventional chives || || beans, peas, parsley || This is a wild cousin of onions and garlic |- |'''Nettle''' || ''[[Urtica dioica]]'' || Broccoli, tomato,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gardenwiseonline.ca/gw/plants/2009/05/08/stinging-nettle-history-and-uses |title=Archived copy |access-date=2010-05-03 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20110706181408/http://www.gardenwiseonline.ca/gw/plants/2009/05/08/stinging-nettle-history-and-uses |archive-date=2011-07-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[Valerian (herb)|valerian]], mint, fennel || || || || Despite its "sting", young plant parts are edible, as is much of the plant when blanched or otherwise prepared. It can be used to make herbal tea || || || Also once grown as a crop for its fiber. Its juice was once used in the place of rennet in cheese-making. It was also a source of "green" for dye. It can still be used as a high-protein additive in animal feed, once dried. |- | '''[[Wild mustard]]''' || ''Brassicaceae'' || Grape vine,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mMtlUK0xVhQC&pg=PA95&lpg=PA95&dq=%22companion+plant%22+%22wild+mustard%22&source=bl&ots=_USJmVe83N&sig=yydlrDxcXJ49Fvq_X8QktoUGSI8&hl=en&ei=T4XdS7PSCpPMMo-EtNUH&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CBgQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22companion+plant%22+%22wild+mustard%22&f=false|title=Roses Love Garlic: Companion Planting and Other Secrets of Flowers|first=Louise|last=Riotte|date=1 January 1998|publisher=Storey Books|via=Google Books}}</ref> radish, non-mustard brassica, including cabbage, cauliflower, broccoli || [[Ladybug]]s || || Traps various brassica pests, including aphids || Seeds and leaves are edible || || beets || Domesticated mustard is a hybrid of three different species of wild mustard, all of which are still used in some places for food. This is known as the [[Triangle of U]]. |- | '''[[Rosa (plant)|Wild rose]]''' || ''Rosa'' || Strawberries, grapes, roses || || Rodents and deer || Traps Japanese beetles || Rose hips can be used in [[herbal tea]]s || || || This includes the feral [[multiflora rose]], brought to the US <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nps.gov/plants/alien/pubs/midatlantic/romu.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=2007-06-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070403013001/http://www.nps.gov/plants/alien/pubs/midatlantic/romu.htm |archive-date=2007-04-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> both for use as root stock for domesticated roses, and as a "natural fence" for livestock. In the mid 20th century miles of multiflora rose hedge were planted in sequence. |}
==Categories of beneficial weeds==
===Pest-repellent=== * [[Neem]]—repels leaf eating insects
===Edible=== * [[Blackberry]]—blackberries are delicious but they form thorny thickets when dead, and their thorn punctures can induce sickness; appropriate medical treatments may thereafter be costly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/lifestyle/home-and-garden/sdut-thorn-punctures-garden-soil-pathogens-2015nov20-story.html|title=Beware thorn punctures; they can make you sick|first=Vincent|last=Lazaneo|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Borage]]—all parts have various medicinal purposes, with the edible flowers being used in desserts. * [[Burdock]]—roots are edible (as are the stalks, but particularly the young leaves <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ediblewildfood.com/burdock.aspx|title=Burdock: Pictures, Flowers, Leaves and Identification - Arctium lappa|website=www.ediblewildfood.com}}</ref>) * [[Chickweed]] (''Stellaria media'')—used in salads and also as ground cover * [[Clover]]—its leaves can be eaten, but not in great numbers due to their natural acidity.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.survival.org.au/bf_trifolium.php|title=Trifolium - Clover - Edible Weeds and Bush Tucker Plant Foods|website=www.survival.org.au}}</ref> * [[Cornflower]]—various colours; can be served as edible garnish to decorate salads. * [[Dandelions]]—leaves are edible, while roots are edible after being roasted * [[Flatweed]]—leaves are edible raw, while roots are edible after being roasted<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.survival.org.au/bf_hypochaeris.php|title=Hypochaeris radicata - Catsears|website=www.survival.org.au}}</ref> * [[Horsetail]]—primeval plant that is high in silica; tops are very similar to & may be eaten like asparagus * [[Lamb's quarter]]s—leaves and shoots, raw, also prevents [[erosion]], also distracts [[leaf miner]]s from nearby crops * [[Nettle]]—young leaves collected before flowering used as a tea or spinach substitute. Plants have use as compost material or for fibre. * [[Purslane]]—prepared raw for salads or sautéed * [[Shepherd's purse]]—leaves are edible and often sautéed or blanched * [[Watercress]]—can be eaten raw or cooked; is considered a weed in some cultures (caution required when harvesting wild because of the risk of contracting potentially fatal liver fluke)
===Habitat for beneficial insects=== * Wild [[blackberry]]—attracts predatory insects, and produces berries * [[Motherwort]]—attracts bees * [[Joe-Pye weed]]—habitat for pollinators and predatory insects * [[Aster (genus)|Aster]]—habitat predatory insects
===Shelter plants=== * Normal [[grass]] can be used as ground cover, especially in nitrogenous soils.
===Trap crops=== [[Trap crop]]s draw potential pests away from the actual crop intended for cultivation.
* [[Cowpea]]—attracts ladybird beetle, so planting around cotton fields protects them from sucking insects. It serves as source of food and niche.
===Other=== * [[Solanaceae|Nightshade]]—breaks up [[hardpan]], allowing roots to grow deeper.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}

page.title: List of national parks of Kenya

revision.text:
The [[national park]] system of [[Kenya]] is maintained by the [[Kenya Wildlife Service]]. There are two main types of terrestrial protected areas in Kenya: national parks, and national reserves; there are also marine parks and marine reserves.
==National parks== * [[Aberdare National Park]] * [[Amboseli National Park]] * [[Arabuko Sokoke National Park]] * [[Central Island National Park]] * [[Chyulu Hills National Park]] * [[Hell's Gate National Park]] * [[Kisite-Mpunguti Marine National Park]] * [[Lake Nakuru National Park]] * [[Malindi Marine National Park]] * [[Malka Mari National Park]] * [[Masai Mara National Park]] * [[Meru National Park]] * [[Mombasa Marine Park]] * [[Mount Elgon National Park]] * [[Mount Kenya National Park]] * [[Mount Longonot National Park]] * [[Nairobi National Park]] * [[Ol Donyo Sabuk National Park]] * [[Ruma National Park]] * [[Saiwa Swamp National Park]] * [[Sibiloi National Park]] * [[Tsavo East National Park]] and [[Tsavo West National Park]] * [[Watamu Marine National Park]] * [[ Mums Center Park]]
== National reserves == * [[Arawale National Reserve]] * [[Bisanadi National Reserve]] * [[Boni National Reserve]] * [[Buffalo Springs National Reserve]] * [[Dodori National Reserve]] * [[Kakamega Forest|Kakamega Forest National Reserve]] * [[Kisumu Impala Sanctuary]] * [[Lake Bogoria National Reserve]] * [[Masai Mara|Masai Mara National Reserve]] * [[Mwaluganje elephant sanctuary]] * [[Mwea National Reserve]] * [[Rimoi National Reserve]]<ref>[http://www.nation.co.ke/counties/Rimoi-National-Reserve-to-open-its-gates-to-tourists/1107872-3118862-yt2h4c/index.html Rimoi National Reserve to open its gates to tourists], Daily Nation, March 16</ref> * [[Samburu National Reserve]] * [[Shimba Hills National Reserve]] * [[Tana River Primate Reserve]] * [[Witu Forest|Witu Forest Reserve (Utwani Forest Reserve)]]
== Marine parks and reserves== * [[Kisite-Mpunguti Marine National Park]] * [[Kiunga Marine National Reserve]] * [[Malindi Marine National Park]] * [[Mombasa Marine National Park and Reserve]] * [[Tana River Primate National Reserve]] * [[Watamu Marine National Park]]
==See also== *[[List of national parks in Africa]] *[[Tourism in Kenya]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Nuclear weapons}} A nuclear close call is an incident that could lead to, or could have led to, at least one unintended nuclear detonation/explosion. These incidents typically involve a perceived imminent threat to a [[nuclear-armed country]] which could lead to retaliatory strikes against the perceived aggressor. The damage caused by international nuclear exchange is not necessarily limited to the participating countries, as the hypothesized rapid [[climate change]] associated with even small-scale regional nuclear war could threaten food production worldwide—a scenario known as [[nuclear famine]].<ref name="agu.org">{{cite journal|last1=Fromm |first1=M. |last2=Stocks |first2=B. |last3=Servranckx |first3=R. |last4=Lindsey |first4=D. |year=2006 |title=Smoke in the Stratosphere: What Wildfires have Taught Us About Nuclear Winter |journal=[[Eos (journal)|Eos, Transactions, American Geophysical Union]] |volume=87 |issue=52 Fall Meet. Suppl. |pages=Abstract U14A–04 |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=American Geophysical Union |url=http://www.agu.org/meetings/fm06/fm06-sessions/fm06_U14A.html |bibcode=2006AGUFM.U14A..04F |display-authors=3 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006085234/http://www.agu.org/meetings/fm06/fm06-sessions/fm06_U14A.html |archivedate=6 October 2014}}</ref>
Despite a reduction in global nuclear tensions after the end of the [[Cold War]], estimated nuclear warhead stockpiles total roughly 15,000 worldwide, with the [[United States]] and [[Russia]] holding 90% of the total.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nuclear Weapons: Who has what at a glance|url=https://www.armscontrol.org/factsheets/Nuclearweaponswhohaswhat|publisher=Arms Control Association}}</ref>
Though exact details on many nuclear close calls are hard to come by, the analysis of particular cases has highlighted the importance of a variety of factors in preventing accidents. At an international level, this includes the importance of context and outside mediation; at the national level, effectiveness in government communications, and involvement of key decision-makers; and, at the individual level, the decisive role of individuals in following intuition and prudent decision-making, often in violation of protocol.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lewis|first1=Patricia|last2=Williams|first2=Heather|last3=Pelopidas|first3=Benoit|last4=Aghlani|first4=Sasan|title=Too Close for Comfort: Cases of Near Nuclear Use and Options for Policy|journal=Chatham House Report|date=28 April 2014|url=https://www.chathamhouse.org/sites/files/chathamhouse/field/field_document/20140428TooCloseforComfortNuclearUseLewisWilliamsPelopidasAghlani.pdf}}</ref>
==1950s and 1960s== ===5 November 1956=== During the [[Suez Crisis]], the [[North American Aerospace Defense Command]] (NORAD) received a number of simultaneous reports, including unidentified aircraft over Turkey, Soviet [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15|MiG-15]] fighters over Syria, a downed British [[English Electric Canberra|Canberra medium bomber]], and unexpected maneuvers by the Soviet [[Black Sea Fleet]] through the [[Dardanelles]] that appeared to signal a Soviet offensive. Considering previous Soviet threats to utilize conventional weapons against France and the UK, U.S. forces believed these events could trigger a [[NATO]] nuclear strike against the Soviet Union. In fact, all reports of Soviet action turned out to be erroneous, misinterpreted, or exaggerated. The perceived threat was due to a coincidental combination of events, including a wedge of swans over Turkey, a fighter escort for the Syrian president returning from Moscow, a British bomber brought down by mechanical issues, and scheduled exercises of the Soviet fleet.<ref name="nuclear files 20">{{cite web|last1=Philips|first1=Alan F.|title=20 Mishaps That Might Have Started Accidental Nuclear War|url=http://nuclearfiles.org/menu/key-issues/nuclear-weapons/issues/accidents/20-mishaps-maybe-caused-nuclear-war.htm|website=Nuclear Files|accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
===5 October 1960=== Radar equipment in [[Thule, Greenland]] mistakenly interpreted a moonrise over Norway as a large-scale Soviet missile launch. Upon receiving a report of the supposed attack, NORAD went on high alert. However, doubts about the authenticity of the attack arose due to the presence of Soviet leader [[Nikita Khrushchev]] in New York as head of the USSR's [[United Nations]] delegation.<ref name="UCS close calls">{{cite web|title=Close Calls with Nuclear Weapons|url=http://www.ucsusa.org/sites/default/files/attach/2015/04/Close%20Calls%20with%20Nuclear%20Weapons.pdf|website=Union of Concerned Scientists|accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref><ref name="K Blows Top">{{cite book |last=Carlson |first=Peter |date=2009 |title=[[K Blows Top]]: A Cold War Comic Interlude Starring Nikita Khrushchev, America's Most Unlikely Tourist |url= |location= |publisher=PublicAffairs |page= |isbn=978-1-58648-497-2}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/13/us/false-alarm-missile-alerts.html|title=Causes of False Missile Alerts: The Sun, the Moon and a 46-Cent Chip|last=Stevens|first=Matt|date=2018|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-14|last2=Mele|first2=Christopher|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
===24 November 1961=== Staff at the Strategic Air Command Headquarters (SAC HQ) simultaneously lost contact with NORAD and multiple [[Ballistic Missile Early Warning System]] sites. Since these communication lines were designed to be redundant and independent from one another, the communications failure was interpreted as either a very unlikely coincidence or a coordinated attack. SAC HQ prepared the entire ready force for takeoff before already-overhead aircraft confirmed that there did not appear to be an attack. It was later found that the failure of a single relay station in Colorado was the sole cause of the communications problem.<ref name="UCS close calls"/>
===27 October 1962=== {{main|Cuban Missile Crisis}} At the height of the Cuban Missile Crisis, Soviet patrol submarine {{ship|Soviet submarine|B-59||2}} almost launched a nuclear-tipped [[torpedo]] while under harassment by American naval forces. One of several vessels surrounded by American [[destroyer]]s near Cuba, ''B-59'' dove to avoid detection and was unable to communicate with Moscow for a number of days.<ref>Michael Dobbs, ''One Minute to Midnight'', Vintage, Random House, 2009.</ref> {{USS|Beale|DD-471|6}} began dropping practice [[depth charge]]s to signal ''B-59'' to surface, however the Soviet submarine took these to be real depth charges.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB75/subchron.htm |title=Chronology of Submarine Contact During the Cuban Missile Crisis |publisher=National Security Archive of the [[George Washington University]] |accessdate=15 November 2010}}</ref> With low [[Battery (electricity)|batteries]] affecting the submarine's life support systems and without orders from [[Moscow]], the commander of ''B-59'' believed that war may have already begun and ordered the use of a 10-kiloton nuclear torpedo against the American fleet. The submarine political officer agreed, but commander of the sub-flotilla [[Vasili Arkhipov]] persuaded the captain to surface and await orders.<ref name="thankyou">{{Cite news|url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/oct/27/vasili-arkhipov-stopped-nuclear-war|title = Thank you Vasili Arkhipov, the man who stopped nuclear war|newspaper = [[The Guardian]]|author = Edward Wilson|date = 2012-10-27|accessdate = 4 August 2016}}</ref><ref name="isbn0-8050-7688-3">{{Cite book|author=[[Noam Chomsky]] |title=Hegemony or Survival: America's Quest for Global Dominance |publisher=Henry Holt |location=New York |year=2004 |isbn=0-8050-7688-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xx3ptbzQ8L4C&pg=PA74 |page=74 |accessdate=}}</ref>
On the same day, an American [[U-2 spy plane]] was shot down over Cuba, and another U-2 flown by [[United States Air Force]] Captain Charles Maultsby strayed {{convert|300|mi|km}} into Soviet airspace. Despite orders to avoid Soviet airspace by at least {{convert|100|mi|km}}, a navigational error took the U-2 over the [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka Peninsula]], causing Soviet MiG interceptors to scramble and pursue the aircraft.<ref name="nuclear files 20"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2008/06/missile_crisis_excerpt200806 |title=Lost in Enemy Airspace |publisher=Vanity Fair |author=Michael Dobbs |date=June 2008 |accessdate=29 August 2016}}</ref> American [[F-102 Delta Dagger|F-102A]] interceptors armed with [[AIM-26 Falcon|GAR-11 Falcon]] nuclear [[air-to-air missile]]s (each with a 0.25 kiloton yield) were then scrambled to escort the U-2 into friendly airspace.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.x-plane.org/home/urf/aviation/text/missiles/aam.html |title=Air-to-air Missile Non-comparison Table |publisher=X-Plane |accessdate=29 August 2016}}</ref> Individual pilots were capable of arming and launching their missiles.
===9 November 1965=== The Command Center of the Office of Emergency Planning went on full alert after a massive power outage in the northeastern United States. Several nuclear bomb detectors—used to distinguish between regular power outages and power outages caused by a nuclear blast—near major U.S. cities malfunctioned due to circuit errors, creating the illusion of a [[nuclear attack]].<ref name="nuclear files 20"/>
===23 May 1967=== A powerful [[solar flare]] accompanied by a [[coronal mass ejection]] interfered with multiple NORAD radars over the Northern Hemisphere. This interference was initially interpreted as intentional jamming of the radars by the Soviets, thus an act of war. A nuclear bomber counter-strike was nearly launched by the U.S.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wall|first1=Michael D.|title=How a 1967 Solar Storm Nearly Led to Nuclear War|url=http://www.space.com/33687-solar-storm-cold-war-false-alarm.html|website=Space.com|date=9 August 2016|accessdate=12 August 2016}}</ref>
==1970s and 1980s== ===9 November 1979=== {{See also|Yom Kippur war|DEFCON}} A [[computer error]] at [[NORAD]] headquarters led to alarm and full preparation for a nonexistent large-scale Soviet attack.<ref name="UCS close calls"/> NORAD notified national security adviser [[Zbigniew Brzezinski]] that the Soviet Union had launched 250 [[ballistic missile]]s with a trajectory for the United States, stating that a decision to retaliate would need to be made by the president within 3 to 7 minutes. NORAD computers then placed the number of incoming missiles at 2,200.<ref name="The 3 A.M. Phone Call">{{cite web |url=http://nsarchive.gwu.edu/nukevault/ebb371/ |title=The 3 A.M. Phone Call |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=1 March 2012 |website=The National Security Archive |publisher=George Washington University |access-date=4 August 2016 |quote=}}</ref> Strategic Air Command was notified, and nuclear bombers prepared for takeoff. Within six to seven minutes of the initial response, satellite and radar systems were able to confirm that the attack was a false alarm.<ref>{{cite web|title=CBC Digital Archives|url=http://www.cbc.ca/archives/entry/norad-false-alarm-causes-uproar|publisher=CBC}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> It was found that a training scenario was inadvertently loaded into an operational computer. Commenting on the incident, U.S. State Department adviser Marshall Shulman stated that "false alerts of this kind are not a rare occurrence. There is a complacency about handling them that disturbs me."<ref name="The 3 A.M. Phone Call"/> In the months following the incident there were 3 more false alarms at NORAD, 2 of them caused by faulty computer chips.<ref name="UCS close calls"/>
===15 March 1980=== One of four Soviet missiles launched from a submarine near the [[Kuril Islands]] was detected by an American early warning sensor and determined to be heading towards the United States.<ref name="UCS close calls"/>
===26 September 1983=== {{Main|1983 Soviet nuclear false alarm incident}} Several weeks after the downing of [[Korean Air Lines Flight 007]] over Soviet airspace, a satellite early-warning system near Moscow reported the launch of one American [[LGM-30 Minuteman|Minuteman ICBM]]. Soon after, it reported that five missiles had been launched. Convinced that a real American offensive would involve many more missiles, Lieutenant Colonel [[Stanislav Petrov]] of the [[Soviet Air Defence Forces|Air Defense Forces]] refused to acknowledge the threat as legitimate and continued to convince his superiors that it was a false alarm until this could be confirmed by ground [[radar]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name="wash">{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/inatl/longterm/coldwar/shatter021099b.htm | title=I Had A Funny Feeling in My Gut | first=David | last=Hoffman | publisher=Washington Post |date=10 February 1999 |access-date= 4 August 2016}}</ref><ref name="Baltimore Sun">{{cite web|title=Cold War's Riskiest Moment |publisher=Baltimore Sun, 31 August 2003 (article reprinted as ''The Nuclear War That Almost Happened in 1983'') |url=http://hnn.us/articles/1709.html#bombs9-5-03 |first=Scott |last=Shane |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819033034/http://hnn.us/articles/1709.html |archivedate=19 August 2006 }}</ref><ref name=AnotherDayRT>{{cite news | title = Another day the world almost ended | url = https://www.rt.com/usa/nuclear-war-stanislav-petrov/ | work = [[RT (TV network)|RT]] | date = May 19, 2010 | access-date = January 17, 2018}}</ref><ref name=PetrovRT>{{cite news | title = 'I was just doing my job': Soviet officer who averted nuclear war dies at age 77 | url = https://www.rt.com/news/403625-nuclear-soviet-officer-died/ | work = RT | date = September 17, 2017 | access-date = January 17, 2018}}</ref><ref name=PetrovBBC>{{cite news | title = Stanislav Petrov, who averted possible nuclear war, dies at 77 | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41314948 | work = [[BBC]] | date = September 18, 2017 | access-date = January 17, 2018}}</ref><ref name=PetrovAP>{{cite news | title = Stanislav Petrov, 'the man who saved the world' from nuclear war, dies at 77 | url = https://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-stanislavsky-petrov-20170921-story.html | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | agency = [[Associated Press]] | date = September 21, 2017 | access-date = January 17, 2018}}</ref><ref name=PetrovNPR>{{cite news | last = Myre | first = Greg | title = Stanislav Petrov, 'The Man Who Saved The World,' Dies At 77 | url = https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/09/18/551792129/stanislav-petrov-the-man-who-saved-the-world-dies-at-77 | work = [[npr]] | date = September 18, 2017 | access-date = January 17, 2018}}</ref><ref name=PetrovSmithsonian>{{cite work | last = Daley | first = Jason | title = Man Who Saved the World From Nuclear Annihilation Dies at 77: In 1983, Soviet lieutenant colonel Stanislav Petrov kept his cool and reported a U.S. missile strike as a false alarm, preventing a massive counterstrike | url = https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/man-who-saved-world-nuclear-annihilation-dies-77-180964934/ | work = [[Smithsonian (magazine)|Smithsonian.com]] | date = September 18, 2017 | access-date = January 17, 2018}}</ref> Two months later, parts of the Soviet government misinterpreted the [[Able Archer 83]] NATO simulation of escalation to DEFCON 1 as a possible ruse of war to obscure preparations for a genuine nuclear first strike.<ref name = "Fischer Conundrum">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/csi-publications/books-and-monographs/a-cold-war-conundrum/source.htm#HEADING1-13|publisher=[[Central Intelligence Agency]]|title=A Cold War Conundrum: The 1983 Soviet War Scare|author =Benjamin B. Fischer|accessdate=January 13, 2009|date=March 17, 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090114024850/https://www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/csi-publications/books-and-monographs/a-cold-war-conundrum/source.htm| archivedate= January 14, 2009 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Post-Cold War== ===25 January 1995=== {{main|Norwegian rocket incident}} Russian President [[Boris Yeltsin]] became the first world leader to activate a [[nuclear briefcase]] after Russian radar systems detected the launch of a Norwegian [[Black Brant XII]] research rocket being used to study the [[Aurora|Northern Lights]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/inatl/longterm/coldwar/shatter031598a.htm|title=Cold-War Doctrines Refuse to Die|first=David|last=Hoffman|publisher=Washington Post Foreign Service|date=15 March 1998}}</ref> Russian strategic [[ballistic missile submarine]]s were put on alert in preparation for a possible retaliatory strike.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eucom.mil/article/23042/this-week-in-eucom-history-january-23-29-1995|title=January 25, 1995—The Norwegian Rocket Incident|publisher=United States European Command|date=23 January 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120921003744/http://www.eucom.mil/article/23042/this-week-in-eucom-history-january-23-29-1995|archivedate=21 September 2012}}</ref> When it became clear the rocket did not pose a threat to Russia and was not part of a larger attack, the alarm was cancelled. Russia was in fact one of a number of countries earlier informed of the launch; however, the information had not reached the Russian radar operators.<ref name="UCS close calls"/>
===23 October 2010=== Commanders at a [[Francis E. Warren Air Force Base|U.S. Air Force base]] in [[Wyoming]] lost most forms of command, control, and security monitoring over 50 nuclear ICBMs for approximately 45 minutes. The missiles were taken offline after a suspected hardware problem caused multiple errors with control computers.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2010/10/failure-shuts-down-squadron-of-nuclear-missiles/65207/ |title=Failure Shuts Down Squadron of Nuclear Missiles |last1=Ambinder |first1=Marc |date=26 October 2010 |publisher=The Atlantic |access-date=11 August 2016}}</ref> Although military officials maintain that the missiles remained under control and were not susceptible to outside attempts to gain control, former Air Force launch officer [[Bruce G. Blair]] expressed concerns that missiles in this status could be vulnerable to launch attempts by [[Hacker (computer security)|hackers]] or compromised missile crews.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://content.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,2030685,00.html?iid=sr-link1 |title=Could Terrorists Launch America's Nuclear Missiles? |last1=Blair |first1=Bruce |date=11 November 2010 |publisher=TIME |access-date=11 August 2016}}</ref>
==See also== {{Columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Sino-Soviet border conflict]] * [[List of military nuclear accidents]] * [[Nuclear and radiation accidents and incidents]] * [[Nuclear winter]] * [[Nuclear terrorism]] * [[Mutually assured destruction]] * [[Vulnerability of nuclear plants to attack]] * [[Cold War II]] * [[World War III]] }}

page.title: List of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2006

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}}
{{Use American English|date=May 2016}} The following is a '''list of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2006'''. It is one of several [[list of pipeline accidents in the United States|lists of U.S. pipeline accidents]]. See also [[list of natural gas and oil production accidents in the United States]]. {{expand list|date=April 2013}} __NOTOC__ <!--begin temporary compact toc--> <!-- something nicer-looking and more navigable should be done here; this is a temporary TOC to ease navigation --> <!-- | bgcolor=#dddddd align=center colspan=11 | See also – [[#References|References]] --> <!--end compact toc-->
== Incidents ==
This is not a complete list of all pipeline accidents. '''For natural gas alone''', the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA), a United States Department of Transportation agency, has collected data on more than 3,200 accidents deemed serious or significant since 1987.
A "significant incident" results in any of the following consequences: * fatality or injury requiring in-patient hospitalization * $50,000 or more in total costs, measured in 1984 dollars * liquid releases of five or more barrels (42 US gal/barrel) * releases resulting in an unintentional fire or explosion
PHMSA and the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) post incident data and results of investigations into accidents involving pipelines that carry a variety of products, including natural gas, oil, diesel fuel, gasoline, kerosene, jet fuel, carbon dioxide, and other substances. Occasionally pipelines are repurposed to carry different products.<ref>Data sets of PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents for 1986-2001, 2002-2009, and 2010-2017 can be downloaded from the tab by that name on the PHMSA's Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10. PHMSA Corrective Action Orders are at https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/CAO_opid_0.html. PHMSA Pipeline Failure Investigation Reports are at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/safety-reports/pipeline-failure-investigation-reports. NTSB Pipeline Accident Reports are at https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/pipeline.aspx.</ref>
* On January 13, a pipeline leak near [[Independence, Kansas]] spilled about 135,000 gallons of petroleum product, of which about 93,000 gallons was lost. The pipeline failed from external corrosion.<ref name="dot4">{{cite web|title=UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION Washington, D.C. 20549 FORM 10-Q |url=https://www.magellanlp.com/uploadedFiles/Investors/Financials/2006/MMP%20-%203q06%2010q%20-%20Final%20Donnelley%20Draft.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101216093213/http://magellanlp.com/uploadedFiles/Investors/Financials/2006/MMP%20-%203q06%2010q%20-%20Final%20Donnelley%20Draft.pdf |archivedate=December 16, 2010 }}</ref> * On February 28, a gas compressor station explosion severely burned a worker, and set off a raging fire near [[De Beque, Colorado]]. A second explosion at that site soon after caused no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc11news.com/home/headlines/2385406.html |title=Man Injured In Natural Gas Explosion |publisher=NBC11news.com |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028044309/http://www.nbc11news.com/home/headlines/2385406.html |archivedate=October 28, 2013 }}</ref> * The [[Prudhoe Bay oil spill]]: On March 2, a surveillance crew discovered a crude oil spill from a [[BP]] crude pipeline near [[North Slope Borough, Alaska]]. The pipeline failure resulted in a release currently estimated at {{convert|5000|oilbbl|m3}} of processed crude oil, impacting the arctic tundra and covering approximately {{convert|2|acre|m2}} of permafrost. The pipeline's leak detection system was not effective in recognizing and identifying the failure. Failure to run [[pigging|cleaning pigs]] to remove internal corrosive build up was a factor. The failure caused crude oil price to spike throughout the World.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 5-2006-501 5H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/520065015H/BP%205-2006-5015H%20-%20Final.pdf?nocache=9340 |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304065542/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/520065015H/BP%205-2006-5015H%20-%20Final.pdf?nocache=9340 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/business/energy/article/Pipe-corrosion-in-Alaska-takes-the-issue-off-back-1899295.php |title=Pipe corrosion in Alaska takes the issue off back burner – Houston Chronicle |publisher=Chron.com |date=August 13, 2006 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010133036/http://www.chron.com/business/energy/article/Pipe-corrosion-in-Alaska-takes-the-issue-off-back-1899295.php |archivedate=October 10, 2012 }}</ref> * On March 23, a pipeline failed west of [[Toledo, Ohio]], spilling about {{convert|200 |oilbbl|m3}} of unleaded gasoline. During the repair work, another smaller nearby leak was also found.<ref>{{cite web|title=Corrective Action Order_03292006 |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320065033H/320065033H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_03292006.pdf |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217225824/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/Comm/reports/enforce/documents/320065033H/320065033H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_03292006.pdf |archivedate=February 17, 2017 }}</ref> * On April 17, a [[Plantation Pipeline]] line experienced a failure in Henrico County, near [[Richmond, Virginia]]. The failure resulted in the release of 23,226 gallons of jet fuel in a residential area. The jet fuel sprayed for approximately 14 minutes and the spray traveled the distance of approximately {{convert|200|ft|m}}. The jet fuel did not ignite.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF NO. 1-2006-5003-H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/120065003H/120065003H_CAO_04202006.pdf?nocache=4592 |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304065757/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/120065003H/120065003H_CAO_04202006.pdf?nocache=4592 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/272047 |title=April 17, 2006 – ProPublica |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020210550/http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/272047 |archivedate=October 20, 2014 }}</ref> * On June 27, a [[Koch Industries]] pipeline carrying crude oil failed near the town of [[Little Falls, Minnesota]]. The pipeline operator estimated that approximately {{convert|3200 |oilbbl|m3}} of crude oil were released. The pipeline failed due to previous mechanical damage to it.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 3-2006-5037H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320065037H/CPF_NO_3-2006-5037H.pdf?nocache=1341 |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304064126/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320065037H/CPF_NO_3-2006-5037H.pdf?nocache=1341 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/272108 |title=June 27, 2006 – ProPublica |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020210552/http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/272108 |archivedate=October 20, 2014 }}</ref> * On July 22, a [[Tennessee Gas Pipeline]] Company gas transmission pipeline ruptured, resulting in an estimated release of {{convert|42946000|cuft|m3|abbr=on}} of natural gas near Clay City in [[Clark County, Kentucky]]. The gas ignited, but there were no injuries, and just minor property damage. External corrosion was suspected.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 2-2006-3 007 H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/220061007H/220061007H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_07272006.pdf |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211183405/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/Comm/Reports/enforce/documents/220061007H/220061007H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_07272006.pdf |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lex18.com/news/gas-explosion-was-kentucky-s-fourth-in-last-decade#!prettyPhoto/0/ |title=Gas Explosion Was Kentucky's Fourth In Last Decade |location=Lexington, Kentucky |publisher=LEX18.com |date=January 3, 2012 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027221607/http://www.lex18.com/news/gas-explosion-was-kentucky-s-fourth-in-last-decade |archivedate=October 27, 2013}}</ref> * On July 22, 2006, near [[Campbellsville, Kentucky]], a Kinder Morgan [[Tennessee Gas Pipeline]] exploded. A 25-foot-long piece of pipe blew out of the ground and landed 200 feet away; the pipe wad twisted and mangled, its external coating burned off. The 24" pipeline ruptured due to an area of external bacterial corrosion more than two feet long at the bottom of a valley in an area of wet shale, known to cause corrosion on buried pipelines in this part of Kentucky. The pipe was manufactured in 1944.<ref>PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents (1986-2001) link on the Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page at www.phmsa.dot.govdata-and-statisticspipelinepipeline-incident-flagged-files. PHMSA Corrective Action Order, CPF No. 2-2006-3 007 H, aka CPF 220061007H. PHMSA data on GT & GG pipelines, 2002-2009.</ref> * On August 7, a leak from a pump on a pipeline, released about 241,000 gallons of HVL's, in [[Jennings, Louisiana]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/272137|title=Aug. 7, 2006 – ProPublica|author=|date=|work=propublica.org|accessdate=May 23, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31554.html?nocache=7376#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications – Operator Information |author= |date= |work=dot.gov |accessdate=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308063412/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31554.html?nocache=7376 |archivedate=March 8, 2016 }}</ref> * On August 12, a Kinder Morgan petroleum pipeline failed in [[Romeoville, Illinois]]. About {{convert|59,000|USgal|L}} of butane were lost. External corrosion was the cause, but there were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_4472.html?nocache=4162#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications |publisher=DOT.gov |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028022217/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_4472.html?nocache=4162 |archivedate=October 28, 2013 }}</ref><ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite web |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/liquid0102.zip |publisher=phmsa.dot.gov |title=liquid0102.zip |accessdate=September 28, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161213203558/http://phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/liquid0102.zip# |archivedate=December 13, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * On September 8, a leak on a pump on an LPG pipeline in [[Apex, North Carolina]] spilled about 12,000 gallons of propane, forcing evacuations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_3445.html?nocache=2146#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications – Operator Information |author= |date= |work=dot.gov |accessdate=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307104148/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_3445.html?nocache=2146 |archivedate=March 7, 2016 }}</ref> * On September 29, a crew replacing an old pipeline hit a high pressure gas pipeline in [[Labette County, Kansas]], killing a crewman. Residents within a mile of the incident were evacuated for a time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2199&dat=20060930&id=sXNUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PzsNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1944,7850067|title=Lawrence Journal-World – Google News Archive Search|publisher=|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref> * On October 12, a pipeline exploded when a tugboat pushing two barges hit that pipeline in West Cote Blanche Bay, about two miles (3 km) from shore and {{convert|100|mi|km}} southwest of [[New Orleans, Louisiana]]. Four crew members were killed, and two were missing and later presumed dead.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,220505,00.html |work=Fox News |title=Searchers Find Body of Fourth Victim of Deadly Louisiana Gas Pipeline Explosion |date=October 13, 2006}}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Dwayne |last=Clark |url=http://lawboat.blogspot.com/2006_10_01_archive.html |title=Jacksonville Florida Maritime Lawyers |publisher=Lawboat.blogspot.com |date=October 5, 2006 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131107005754/http://lawboat.blogspot.com/2006_10_01_archive.html |archivedate=November 7, 2013 }}</ref> * On October 25, an ammonia pipeline failed from corrosion near [[Clay Center, Kansas]], releasing about 4500 barrels of ammonia. two people were injured by the fumes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31618.html |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications |publisher=DOT.gov |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121008190226/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31618.html |archivedate=October 8, 2012 }}</ref> * On November 11, 2006, near [[Cheyenne, Wyoming]], a jet-black, {{convert|300|acre|km2|adj=on}} burn site surrounded the skeletal hulk of a bulldozer that struck the Rockies Express (REX) natural-gas pipeline, setting off an explosion and fire. The bulldozer operator was killed. The subcontractor did not know there was another pipeline there because no one had marked the position of the existing pipeline. The company building the new pipeline was fined $2.3 million for failing to obtain a location for the other pipeline.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,228843,00.html |title=1 Dead After Wyoming Gas Pipeline Explodes |publisher=Fox News |date=November 11, 2006 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071208135236/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0%2C2933%2C228843%2C00.html |archivedate=December 8, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/12/01/el-paso-corp-fined-23-mil_n_375774.html |work=Huffington Post |title=El Paso Corp. Fined $2.3 million For Wyoming Pipeline Explosion |date=December 1, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031054223/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/12/01/el-paso-corp-fined-23-mil_n_375774.html |archivedate=October 31, 2013}}</ref> Two months after this explosion, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission threatened to shut the project down if REX didn’t improve its “poor compliance record” involving construction activity outside the approved work area.<ref>Tom Beyerlein, “Fatal explosion puts Kinder Morgan’s past in spotlight,” ''Dayton Daily News'' [Ohio], September 14, 2008, in Tar Sands Free BC, September 15, 2008, http://tarsandsfreebc.org/?p=236, accessed June 16, 2014.</ref> * On or about November 27, 2006, approximately 97 barrels of gasoline were discharged from a portion of [[Plantation Pipeline]] in [[Mecklenburg County, North Carolina]], into Paw Creek and its adjoining shorelines. The leak resulted from a failed gasket on an above-ground block valve.<ref name="epa.gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/compliance/resources/decrees/civil/cwa/plantationpipeline-cd.pdf |title=UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, and STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA, Plaintiffs, v. PLANTATION PIPE LINE COMPANY, Civil Action No. 3:08-cv-500 |accessdate=June 14, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028061446/http://www.epa.gov/compliance/resources/decrees/civil/cwa/plantationpipeline-cd.pdf |archivedate=October 28, 2013 |df= }}</ref> * '''[[2006 Falk Corporation explosion]]''': Leaks in a [[Milwaukee|Milwaukee, Wisconsin]] propane pipe running below an apartment building caused an explosion. Three people were killed and forty-seven others injured. * On December 19, a lineman for Midwest Energy hit a natural gas transmission pipeline near [[Mason, Michigan]]. The lineman was killed in the following explosion and fire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.msn.com/us/pipeline-explosions-from-around-the-united-states#image=7|title=News|publisher=|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/safety/IncDetSt_st_MI_flt_sig.html?nocache=2203 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications |website=Primis.phmsa.dot.gov |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022132814/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/safety/IncDetSt_st_MI_flt_sig.html?nocache=2203 |archivedate=October 22, 2014 }}</ref> * On December 24, a [[Plains All American Pipeline]] ruptured, spilling about 23,856 gallons of crude oil in the [[Gulf of Mexico]], about 30 miles southeast of [[Galveston, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=20061227&id=NKE_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=alYMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1187,1165867|title=The Victoria Advocate – Google News Archive Search|publisher=|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/272243 |title=Dec. 24, 2006 – ProPublica |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020210647/http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/272243 |archivedate=October 20, 2014 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}} {{List of pipeline accidents in the United States|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Lists of pipeline accidents in the United States]] [[Category:2006 disasters in the United States]]

This is a '''list of [[river]]s of [[Thailand]]'''. The rivers are arranged alphabetically within their respective provinces or special governed districts. The same river may be found in more than one province as many rivers cross province borders.
[[Image:Wat Arun Bangkok View Photo D Ramey Logan.jpg|thumb|350px|right|The [[Chao Phraya River]] in [[Bangkok]]]]

===Nakhon Ratchasima=== * [[Mun River]]
===Nakhon Sawan=== * [[Chao Phraya River]] * [[Nan River]] * [[Ping River]] * [[Sakae Krang River]] * [[Yom River]]
